Replace Future Instances

Replace Instances with Code
LIFE323
Notes
This module is due to commence in September 2020

Overview

Overview
This module aims to provide students with a systematic knowledge and critical understanding of how patterns of gene expression in an organism alter in response to environmental changes, growth and development;

It will explain the steps at which control of gene expression can be exerted, focusing on eukaryotic cells;

The module will be taught through lectures and assessed by two coursework assessments.
Educational Aims
To provide students with a systematic knowledge and critical understanding of how living organisms control their pattern of gene expression;

To describe how patterns of gene expression respond to environmental factors during growth and development;

To explain current knowledge of the steps at which control of gene expression in eukaryotic cells occurs.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module aims to provide students with a systematic knowledge and critical understanding of how patterns of gene expression in an organism alter in response to environmental changes, growth and development;

It will explain the steps at which control of gene expression can be exerted, focusing on eukaryotic cells;

The module will be taught through lectures and assessed by two coursework assessments.
Outline Syllabus
Topic One: Transcription and its regulation;

RNAPII recruitment and modification; co-transcriptional regulation;

Nuclear organisation and epigenetic regulation;

Topic Two: Chromosome territories, nuclear architecture and gene regulation;

Epigenetic regulation: DNA methylation; histone modification and the histone code;

Topic Three: The role and regulation of RNA;

RNA processing, transport and localisation, regulation of mRNA stability;

Non-coding RNAs: production, mechanism of action and roles;

Topic Four: Mathematical modelling biological networks;

Topic Five: Gene Expression in Biological Systems with reference to at least two case studies

Genetic control of stem-cell fate and development.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1: Asynchronous online lectures followed by timetabled synchronous online sessions.
Teaching method 2: Timetabled face-to-face sessions.
Teaching method 3: Self-directed learning aided by formative online tests and directed online resources

Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include PBL, flipped classrooms, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lecture content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Description:
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: This refers to timetabled lectures sessions

Teaching Method 4 - Assessment
Description:
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: This refers to scheduled times for summative assessments

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
There will be two cycles of open book assessment. Assessment 1, mid-term (40% of the marks); and Assessment 2, end of term (60% of the marks), allowing the opportunity to improve following feedback from cycle 1. Assessments will be directed at research papers set by the lecturers, with questions focusing on interpretation, analysis and problem solving.

The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Specifically, these assessments enhance digital fluency in our students, a skill highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their field. These authentic assessments are research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 ​To evaluate current knowledge and understanding of how and where expression in eukaryotes is regulated
 LO2 ​To critically discuss the role and regulation of RNA synthesis, processing, stability and transport
 LO3 ​To compare and contrast model developmental systems such as plant flowering and early embryonic development in Drosophila
 LO4 ​To synthesise information, critically review evidence to support conclusions, and define complex genetic problems by applying appropriate knowledge and skills
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Improving own learning/performance - Self-awareness/self-analysis

The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Specifically, these assessments enhance digital fluency in our students, a skill highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their field. These authentic assessments are research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

 LO2 ​To critically discuss the role and regulation of RNA synthesis, processing, stability and transport
 LO3 ​To compare and contrast model developmental systems such as plant flowering and early embryonic development in Drosophila
 LO4 ​To synthesise information, critically review evidence to support conclusions, and define complex genetic problems by applying appropriate knowledge and skills

LIFE323
Notes
This module is due to commence in September 2020

Overview

Overview
This module aims to provide students with a systematic knowledge and critical understanding of how patterns of gene expression in an organism alter in response to environmental changes, growth and development;

It will explain the steps at which control of gene expression can be exerted, focusing on eukaryotic cells;

The module will be taught through lectures and assessed by two coursework assessments.
Educational Aims
To provide students with a systematic knowledge and critical understanding of how living organisms control their pattern of gene expression;

To describe how patterns of gene expression respond to environmental factors during growth and development;

To explain current knowledge of the steps at which control of gene expression in eukaryotic cells occurs.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module aims to provide students with a systematic knowledge and critical understanding of how patterns of gene expression in an organism alter in response to environmental changes, growth and development;

It will explain the steps at which control of gene expression can be exerted, focusing on eukaryotic cells;

The module will be taught through lectures and assessed by two coursework assessments.
Outline Syllabus
Topic One: Transcription and its regulation;

RNAPII recruitment and modification; co-transcriptional regulation;

Nuclear organisation and epigenetic regulation;

Topic Two: Chromosome territories, nuclear architecture and gene regulation;

Epigenetic regulation: DNA methylation; histone modification and the histone code;

Topic Three: The role and regulation of RNA;

RNA processing, transport and localisation, regulation of mRNA stability;

Non-coding RNAs: production, mechanism of action and roles;

Topic Four: Mathematical modelling biological networks;

Topic Five: Gene Expression in Biological Systems with reference to at least two case studies

Genetic control of stem-cell fate and development.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1: Asynchronous online lectures followed by timetabled synchronous online sessions.
Teaching method 2: Timetabled face-to-face sessions.
Teaching method 3: Self-directed learning aided by formative online tests and directed online resources

Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include PBL, flipped classrooms, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lecture content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Description:
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: This refers to timetabled lectures sessions

Teaching Method 4 - Assessment
Description:
Attendance Recorded: Yes
Notes: This refers to scheduled times for summative assessments

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
There will be two cycles of open book assessment. Assessment 1, mid-term (40% of the marks); and Assessment 2, end of term (60% of the marks), allowing the opportunity to improve following feedback from cycle 1. Assessments will be directed at research papers set by the lecturers, with questions focusing on interpretation, analysis and problem solving.

The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Specifically, these assessments enhance digital fluency in our students, a skill highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their field. These authentic assessments are research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Notes
This module is due to commence in September 2020

Overview

Overview
This module aims to provide students with a systematic knowledge and critical understanding of how patterns of gene expression in an organism alter in response to environmental changes, growth and development;

It will explain the steps at which control of gene expression can be exerted, focusing on eukaryotic cells;

The module will be taught through lectures and assessed by two coursework assessments.
Educational Aims
To provide students with a systematic knowledge and critical understanding of how living organisms control their pattern of gene expression;

To describe how patterns of gene expression respond to environmental factors during growth and development;

To explain current knowledge of the steps at which control of gene expression in eukaryotic cells occurs.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module aims to provide students with a systematic knowledge and critical understanding of how patterns of gene expression in an organism alter in response to environmental changes, growth and development;

It will explain the steps at which control of gene expression can be exerted, focusing on eukaryotic cells;

The module will be taught through lectures and assessed by two coursework assessments.
Outline Syllabus
Topic One: Transcription and its regulation;

RNAPII recruitment and modification; co-transcriptional regulation;

Nuclear organisation and epigenetic regulation;

Topic Two: Chromosome territories, nuclear architecture and gene regulation;

Epigenetic regulation: DNA methylation; histone modification and the histone code;

Topic Three: The role and regulation of RNA;

RNA processing, transport and localisation, regulation of mRNA stability;

Non-coding RNAs: production, mechanism of action and roles;

Topic Four: Mathematical modelling biological networks;

Topic Five: Gene Expression in Biological Systems with reference to at least two case studies

Genetic control of stem-cell fate and development.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1: Asynchronous online lectures followed by timetabled synchronous online sessions.
Teaching method 2: Timetabled face-to-face sessions.
Teaching method 3: Self-directed learning aided by formative online tests and directed online resources

Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include PBL, flipped classrooms, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework.

Lecture content, reading lists, and discussion between students and staff give the students an opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this inclusive approach fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their global perspective (Global citizenship and Inclusivity, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Teaching Method 4 - Assessment

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
There will be two cycles of open book assessment. Assessment 1, mid-term (40% of the marks); and Assessment 2, end of term (60% of the marks), allowing the opportunity to improve following feedback from cycle 1. Assessments will be directed at research papers set by the lecturers, with questions focusing on interpretation, analysis and problem solving.

The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Specifically, these assessments enhance digital fluency in our students, a skill highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their field. These authentic assessments are research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 ​To evaluate current knowledge and understanding of how and where expression in eukaryotes is regulated
 LO2 ​To critically discuss the role and regulation of RNA synthesis, processing, stability and transport
 LO3 ​To compare and contrast model developmental systems such as plant flowering and early embryonic development in Drosophila
 LO4 ​To synthesise information, critically review evidence to support conclusions, and define complex genetic problems by applying appropriate knowledge and skills
